tkg/guest-cluster.html.title: Guest Cluster
tkg/guest-cluster.html.description:
#tenancy
Once a workload cluster (TKG) is bound to a Supervisor Namespace: ✅ The cluster knows which Supervisor Namespace it lives in ❌ It has no intrinsic knowledge of: Organization Project Automation constructs Approval flows Business tenancy
^ all of these concepts stop at the **VCF Automation boundary.
When a workload cluster is bound to a Supervisor Namespace, we are talking about a TKG workload cluster created by the vSphere Supervisor.That implies: The cluster is created via Supervisor APIs
It is vSphere Namespaces-scoped It is lifecycle-managed by vSphere It runs on ESX using VM-based worker nodes So, in this model:
Guest cluster == TKG workload cluster

tkg/tkg.html.title: TKG
tkg/tkg.html.description:
TKG (Tanzu Kubernetes Grid) is VMware’s CNCF-conformant Kubernetes distribution, integrated deeply with vSphere.TKG, in this context is: Upstream Kubernetes + VMware’s opinionated lifecycle, security, and infrastructure integration. Runs on vSphere Worker nodes are VMs
Created and managed via vSphere Supervisor Tightly integrated with:
vSphere networking (NSX / VDS)
vSphere storage (vSAN, CNS) vSphere IAM / RBAC boundaries Inside the guest cluster: Kubernetes sees: Namespaces RBAC CRDs Workloads It does not see: Organizations Projects Approval flows Business tenancy Those live outside the cluster, enforced by:
vSphere
vSphere Supervisor
Automation layers (i.e., VCF Automation) This is similar to saying “a Docker container does not know which Jira project paid for the VM it runs on”.vSphere / ESX └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace └── TKG Workload Cluster (guest cluster) ├── Kubernetes API ├── Nodes = VMs └── Apps / Pods

vcf/main-componets/engine/nsx/nsx.html.title: NSX
vcf/main-componets/engine/nsx/nsx.html.description:
NSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX brings networking services closer to the application, whether running on virtual machines (VMs), containers or physical servers. This allows for a cloud operating model where networks can be provisioned and managed independently of the underlying hardware.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the  Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture. Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane. You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. You enable multi-tenant deployment and consumption of NSX services for the provider administrator and the tenants or organizations.
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
#tenancy

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/cloud-se.title: Cloud Services
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/cloud-se.description:
VCF Automation (VCF-A) provides a set of cloud services which are accessible on a self-service basis using multiple interfaces, including UI, CLI, and API.
With this interface, users can provision the following types of workloads: VMs Kubernetes workloads Networking Volumes Secret stores Databases Harbor container registries External DNS Certificates AI workloads
Additionally, application teams can also provision resources on a self-service basis from Catalogs which are backed by pre-configured workload templates. These self-service options help developers focus on application development instead of managing the underlying infrastructure.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/organiza.title: Organization Management
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/organiza.description:
VCF Automation improves governance for users and resources by enabling organization administrators create and assign projects and vSphere Namespaces tailored for different application teams.
#todo make a list of roles and what capabilities each these roles do. For example, "what does an 'organization administrator' do; what are other kinds of admins?"
Organization administrators can set resource limits and policies while delegating network management through Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) for application teams.
Additionally, Policy as Code enables organization administrators to enforce instance-centric policies for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) resources from a central location for compliance and reducing the risk of human error.

This capability provides isolated environments with dedicated network setup. IT Teams and CSPs can monitor resource usage, control permissions, and provide managed services while ensuring security through comprehensive network isolation.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/vcf-auto.title: VCF Automation
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-a/vcf-auto.description:
enables IT teams and cloud service providers (CSPs) to deliver a self-service private cloud for AI, Kubernetes, and VM-based applications.
The solution simplifies the process of provisioning and scaling a multi-tenant private cloud with out-of-the-box Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offerings, accelerating the time to market for applications while maintaining control using policy-based governance.VCF Automation provides governance at the request and lifecycle level—controlling who can deploy which patterns, under what constraints and approvals—while runtime security, drift detection, and continuous enforcement are handled by downstream platforms.
Governance
#tenancyVCF Automation has the following capabilities:
Cloud Services: Provides a set of cloud services to meet the needs of application teams
Provider Management: Supports IT teams and cloud service providers to effectively manage, deliver, and scale cloud services across multiple vCenter and VCF instances.
Organization Management: Provides capabilities that enable the organization administrator of a Line of Business or a tenant to further organize and govern resources allocated to them among application teams.
vSphere Supervisor: Provides the capability to run Kubernetes workloads directly on ESX hosts and to create upstream Kubernetes clusters within dedicated namespaces.( #todo: Further explanation needed )

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/security.description:
The security management area of VCF Operations includes capabilities such as Security Operations, Event Auditing, and Compliance Checks.
Security Operations: The Security Operations dashboard is designed to provide a comprehensive view of your security posture in VCF.
Events Auditing: Event auditing provides visibility into platform interaction changes across the VCF infrastructure and insights into suspicious access events and policy violations. Compliance: Ensure compliance for your VCF infrastructure and cloud environments against optimum configurations, maintaining a consistent configuration across SDDC components, reducing organizational and business risk.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/vcf-oper.title: VCF Operations
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/vcf-oper.description:
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF Operations has these functional areas: Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
Workload Mobility Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/workload.title: Workload Mobility
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/workload.description: VCF Operations HCX is a workload mobility platform for migration and interconnection of workloads within and across VCF private clouds.You can perform secure and automated migrations without requiring changes to applications or network configurations. Important features include multiple migration types, such as live and bulk migration, as well as network extension, which preserves existing IP addresses and network topologies. Thus, you can place workloads based on business requirements. The platform minimizes downtime during migrations, improves scalability, and supports compliance and security throughout workload transitions.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/workload.title: Workload Operations
vcf/main-componets/engine/vcf-o/workload.description: Workload operations ensure that critical applications are running properly by monitoring its performance, availability and end-user experience. For container-based applications, VCF Operations provides native integration with vSphere Supervisor which enables automatic monitoring of Supervisor instances and vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS) clusters at a granular level, shortening troubleshooting time.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vsan/vsan.html.title: vSAN
vcf/main-componets/engine/vsan/vsan.html.description:
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage pool shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vsphere/vspher.title: vSphere
vcf/main-componets/engine/vsphere/vspher.description:
At its core, it is a compute, storage, and network abstraction layer: A distributed operating system for data centers.It manages large collections of infrastructure, such as CPUs, storage, networking, GPUs, and DPUs as a seamless and dynamic operating environment, and also manages the complexity of a data center.  It virtualizes physical infrastructure into managed CPU, storage, and networking resources.vSphere ├── ESXi (data plane) ├── vCenter Server (control plane) └── Integrated services (HA, DRS, vMotion, etc.) vSphere is a distributed system that provides the following;vSphere is a datacenter operating system.The two core components of VMware vSphere: ESX
and vCenter
High Availability with vSphere automatically restarts your VMs following physical machine failure.
Fault Tolerance provides continuous availability of any application in the event of a hardware failure with no data loss or downtime.
vMotion enables live migration of virtual machines with no disruption to users or loss of service, eliminating the need to schedule application downtime for planned server maintenance. Storage vMotion avoids downtime for planned storage maintenance. Identity federation with Microsoft Entra ID, ADFS and Okta. Virtual Machine Encryption: Data-at-rest encryption for virtual machine data and disks.
vSphere Trust Authority: Remote attestation for sensitive workloads.

vcf/main-componets/engine/vsphere-superv.title: vSphere Supervisor
vcf/main-componets/engine/vsphere-superv.description:
The vSphere Supervisor lives as a set of Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts, instantiated, wired, and governed by vCenter Server.

Runs on: ESX Created and managed by: VMware vCenter Server Implemented as: Kubernetes control-plane VMs
Distributed across ESX hosts
Backed by vSAN / datastores
Networked via NSX (or VDS in simpler setups) When you “enable Supervisor” in vCenter: vCenter: Creates a special-purpose Kubernetes cluster Instantiates its control plane as VMs Pins it tightly to: Cluster membership Networking Storage Treats it as part of the infrastructure, not a tenant workload So the Supervisor is: Not a workload cluster Not user-managed Kubernetes Not a vSphere product you install It is an infrastructure service owned by vCenter.Physical Hosts └─ ESX └─ vCenter Server (control plane) └─ Supervisor Cluster (Kubernetes control plane VMs) ├─ Supervisor Namespaces ├─ vSphere Pods └─ Guest / Workload Clusters The vSphere Supervisor is a Kubernetes control plane deployed as system-managed VMs on ESX, whose lifecycle is owned entirely by vCenter Server and whose purpose is to expose Kubernetes semantics directly on vSphere infrastructure. The vSphere Supervisor physically lives as vCenter-managed Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts inside a vSphere cluster.
vSphere Supervisor is the foundation of VCF consumption and can be enabled during workload domain creation or directly in vCenter.
#todo "consumption" is discussed in several meetings. It seems like standard nomenclature. Learn what it is.
#todo Is vSphere Supervisor a type of vSphere deployment. Follow-up: what really is vSphere? Is it part of VCF-A or VCF-O? It transforms vSphere clusters into modern application platforms by embedding a platform-level Kubernetes control plane directly into ESX hosts, exposing a unified declarative API surface.
This integration allows end users to provision and manage workloads, including VMs, containers via vSphere Pods, full Kubernetes clusters through VKS, OCI image registries, and data services through a consistent API interface.
#todo what kinds or registries, "bring your own", harbor, cloud? all?
#todo why embedding the control plane into ESX hosts is such a big thing? wasn't that possible before. Isn't an ESX a "linux machine" at a high level anyway? What makes this so unique and innovative?
#todo is the "unified declarative API surface" k8s API, and custom resources? What kind(s) of Custom Resources?
#todo what "really" is a vSphere Pod? Enough with all the marketing language!
vSphere Supervisor maintains enterprise-grade governance, security, and operational consistency through vCenter, VCF Operations, and VCF Automation.
#todo is vSphere Supervisor a higher-level abstraction around the above; or is it a separate entity that communicates (i.e. supervises) those sub-entities?
vSphere Supervisor's vSphere Namespaces provide the foundation for multi-tenancy, enabling GitOps-based workflows, and delivering cloud-like self-service in private data centers.
#todo so tenancy is namespace-bound?
#tenancy
Use NSX Virtual Private Clouds (VPC) workload networks. This configuration is a requirement for using VCF Automation
Determine if a Single-Zone Supervisor or Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment is required: In VCF 9.0, a Supervisor deployed in a single-zone configuration cannot be converted to a multi-zone deployment after enablement. You must determine the target deployment model before initiating the Supervisor enablement process.
#todo what is single-zone versus multi-zone? Single-Zone Deployment: A Single-Zone Supervisor deployment uses a single vSphere cluster to host both workloads and Supervisor management components.
Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these zones are used exclusively for workload placement and do not host Supervisor control plane components.
#todo what are Supervisor control plane components?
Multi-Zone Deployment: A Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment uses three vSphere clusters, placing each cluster into a vSphere Zone. vSphere Zones are used by workloads and Supervisor management components to deliver high availability and expose each cluster as an independent, consumable availability zone. This configuration provides a resilient, HA-capable platform. Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these additional zones are available for workload consumption only, not for Supervisor control plane components. Single Host: Also a Single-Zone Supervisor with a single Control Plane VM deployed to a single ESX host, with vSphere HA disabled. While it shares the same characteristics as other single-zone deployments, in this configuration, any host failure results in downtime for the Supervisor Control Plane and potentially for associated workloads.
Easy Supervisor: This is a Single-Zone simplified deployment that uses workload networking on top of vSphere Distributed Switch, designed as a fast and simple starting point for proof-of-concept environments and production deployments leveraging vSphere Distributed Switch. An Easy Supervisor deployment consists of: One Supervisor Control Plane VM A shared network for both workload and management traffic No load balancer
#todo does that imply that normally workload and management traffic is spilt?
It is vSphere running in special Kubernetes-enabled mode.
VCF Automation consumes what Supervisor exposes.
You can think of Supervisor as vSphere with Kubernetes fused into its control plane.


When you enable Supervisor on a vSphere cluster, you are activating a capability inside vSphere.
Supervisor runs inside ESX.
Uses vCenter as the control plane.
Creates Supervisor Namespaces. Exposes Kubernetes APIs, backed by native vSphere primitives. So conceptually, Supervisor is vSphere operating in "Kubernetes-native mode".
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces.If classic vSphere is "run VMs", Supervisor vSphere is "Run anything (VMs, Pods, services)" with the same primitives.
Supervisor runs on ESX. It enables Kubernetes semantics backed by vSphere primitives.
VCF Automation is optional and sits above Supervisor.
Supervisor Namespaces look like Kubernetes namespace on purpose.vSphere (authoritative substrate) └── Supervisor ├── Kubernetes API (authoritative for some things) └── vSphere API/UI (authoritative for others) There is no promise that: every UI action has a YAML equivalent or that YAML is the “source of truth” for all infra Instead: some things are Kubernetes-first some things remain vSphere-first Kubernetes manifest → vSphere policy enforcement. Create VMs via VirtualMachine CRDs (VM Operator) Create Pods / Deployments Attach storage Attach networks (within guardrails) PVCs backed by vSphere storage policies Datastore selection via StorageClasses Policy-based placement Declare “I need this secret” Injector materializes it VCF Secret Service enforces access
Pods/VMs attach to NSX-backed segments Load balancers exposed via K8s Service abstractions You don’t manage NSX topology in YAML, but you consume it declaratively. Infrastructure topology Tenancy and Governance constructs (Organization, Projects, Quoatas at Provider level, Approval, Chargeback) Those live in VCF Automation / vSphere UI, not Kubernetes. So: vSphere Supervisor exposes a Kubernetes-native API surface for workload consumption (pods, VMs, storage, networking), while infrastructure topology, tenancy, and governance remain vSphere- and Automation-controlled.

vcf/governance.html.title: Governance
vcf/governance.html.description:
Governance in VCF is the set of mechanisms that decide who is allowed to request which platform capabilities, under what constraints, with what approvals, and for how long — before anything is created.VCF Automation governs entitlement and lifecycle decisions, including lease expiry and grace periods, but vSphere Supervisor remains the execution authority and only acts when Automation explicitly requests a change. VCF-A governance is front-door, human-aware, policy-driven It’s about entitlement, approval, and lifecycle It is not a security monitoring system It is not a Terraform-style reconciler It is exactly what service providers and large enterprises need to avoid chaos What Governance is not:Governance does not watch workloads. It decides whether they are allowed to exist in the first place.Governance (VCF Automation) ├── Organizations ├── Projects ├── Blueprints ├── Entitlements ├── Approvals ├── Quotas └── Leases Execution (vSphere / Supervisor) ├── Namespaces ├── Resource pools ├── Networks └── Workloads Nothing in the execution layer knowns governance exists. Governance defines who may open the door. Execution decides what happens after they are inside the house. In other words, governance is “pre-creation” control, not runtime policing.

kubectl-in-supervisorlandia.html.title: Kubectl in Supervisorlandia
kubectl-in-supervisorlandia.html.description:
Connected to Supervisor Cluster:kubectl config use-context <supervisor-context> kubectl get ns NAME STATUS AGE default Active kube-system Active kube-public Active kube-node-lease Active my-team-a Active my-team-b Active Here, there is no such thing as a “regular Kubernetes namespace” in the tenant sense. The namespace here: Cannot be created freely. Map to vSphere inventory objects. Quotas, storage, and networking are externally-enforced. Connected to a guest clusterkubectl get ns kubectl create ns foo kubectl delete ns foo All of these will work as expected. Supervisor namespaces → owns the cluster. Guest cluster namespace → normal Kubernetes semantics. # check Supervisor-specific APIs kubectl api-resources | grep -i vm virtualmachines vmoperator.vmware.com # look at the nodes kubectl get nodes -o wide # look for VM Operator kubectl get pods -A | grep vmoperator Supervisor cluster nodes typically show:
ESX-backed control-plane VMs. Special node labels VM Operator components Guest clusters look like: Standard linux nodes kubelet-managed lifecycle No VM Operator CRDs. In a Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are Kubernetes namespaces whose lifecycle, limits, and security are owned by vSphere. In a guest cluster, namespaces are owned entirely by Kubernetes.
#tenancy

supervisor-namespace.html.title: Supervisor Namespace
supervisor-namespace.html.description:
These are not Kubernetes namespaces in the usual sense. They are: Resource-governed containers Backed by: vSphere Networking (NSX)
vSphere Storage (VSAN) vSphere RBAC A tenant can have more than one Supervisor Namespace; however, those namespaces are not individual tenants. Tenancy is a business/trust concept. Supervisor Namespaces are execution slices that implement tenancy. vCenter / API / UI ↓ Supervisor Namespace created ↓ Namespace appears in Kubernetes ↓ kubectl can now interact with it ^ This is the opposite of upstream Kubernetes.In a vSphere Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are created and owned by vSphere as Supervisor Namespaces. Kubernetes users cannot create namespaces directly; kubectl is used only to interact with namespaces after vSphere has provisioned them. Supervisor Namespaces are created by vSphere
kubectl create ns is not how tenancy is established. This will be explicitly denies on the Supervisor Cluster. There is no concept of a regular tenant namespace on Supervisor Kubernetes reflects what vSphere creates Namespace lifecycle is deliberately centralized for safety In a Supervisor cluster, Kubernetes cluster-admin privileges do not grant authority over physical resource allocation. Namespace creation and resource envelopes are owned by vSphere, and Kubernetes operates strictly within those bounds.Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-prod ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-dev Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-coke-us ├── ns-coke-eu └── ns-coke-apac ## VCF Automation Representation Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev ^ One organization, multiple projects, Each project maps to (ideally) one Supervisor Namespace. But this is also possible: Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod The only inverant is one supervisor namespace cannot belong to multiple projects. Namespaces are unique per supervisor cluster. Supervisor clusters are *isolation domains*, so global uniqueness enforcement would have been 1) artificial and 2) painful. Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) From vSphere's perspective, a Pod, VM, or VM-based Pod is just scheduled compute.Project is an automation construct. Defined by Automation Admin persona. Mapped to one or more Supervisor Namespaces. Invisible to vSphere / Kubernetes. Their purpose is to govern requests, not execution.
From the Guest Cluster’s perspective, Organizations and Projects do not exist; similarly there is no concept of an organization or project inside the Supervisor Cluster either.Supervisor namespaces intentionally mimic Kubernetes semantics:From the developer's laptop, they feel like ordinary Kubernetes namespaces.Here is where they differ though (mostly around ownership and LCM)in Supervisor namespaces, resource governance is outside Kubernetes.In Kubernetes: CPU/memory limits = ResourceQuota Storage = StorageClass + PVC Network = CNI rules In Supervisor: CPU/memory = vSphere resource pools Storage = datastore policies Network = NSX segments Limits are hard boundaries, not advisory So when you say: "This namespace gets 8 vCPU and 64 GB RAM" That's not a Kubernetes promise---that's vSphere enforcing physics.Security model is in vSphere, not in KubernetesKubernetes RBAC applies inside the box vSphere already drew.That’s why certain Kubernetes admin actions are silently blocked even when RBAC says “allowed”.From Kubernetes’ POV: It looks like a CNI plugin In reality: NSX owns: L2/L3 segments Firewall rules Load balancers Kubernetes asks politely. NSX decides.This matters for: NetworkPolicy Ingress behavior Multi-tenant isolation In vanilla K8s: PVC requests storage Cluster tries to satisfy it In Supervisor: PVC must map to pre-approved storage policies Datastore capabilities are enforced externally StorageClass ≈ view of vSphere policy, not a free-form construct.The goal of this abstraction is to: Let Kubernetes users feel at home Let infrastructure teams retain determinism Avoid “Kubernetes ate my datacenter” chaos So Supervisor namespaces are: Kubernetes-compatible interfaces to vSphere-owned sandboxes Supervisor namespaces intentionally impersonate Kubernetes namespaces Kubernetes sees them as native; operations are externally enforced vSphere owns: lifecycle resource limits security boundaries Kubernetes operates within those constraints Supervisor Namespace names are unique only within a Supervisor cluster, and every Supervisor Namespace is governed by exactly one Project; Organizations do not directly own namespaces.Supervisor Namespace names are not globally unique, nor organization-wide unique.
They are unique per Supervisor Cluster.
Supervisor Namespaces are always associated with a Project.Organization └── Project └── Supervisor Namespace(s) Namespace names are: ❌ not global ❌ not org-unique ❌ not project-unique ✅ unique per Supervisor cluster Namespace: belongs to exactly one Project indirectly belongs to one Organization never floats independently Here’s a concrete example:Org: Verizon Project: West-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: sjc-01 - Namespace: edge-prod - Supervisor Cluster: lax-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← same name, totally fine Project: East-Coast - Supervisor Cluster: iad-01 - Namespace: edge-prod ← also fine
Namespace names are Supervisor Cluster-scoped Projects are mandatory governance owners Organizations are containers of projects, not namespaces Any apparent contradiction is UI simplification, not platform behavior

supervisor-vcf-a-relationshipt.html.title: Supervisor-VCF-A Relationshipt
supervisor-vcf-a-relationshipt.html.description: ┌────────────────────────────┐ │ VCF Automation (vRA) │ ← lifecycle, blueprints, polic ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere Supervisor │ ← Kubernetes-native control plane ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere (ESX + vCenter) │ ← compute, storage, networking ├────────────────────────────┤ │ Hardware │ └────────────────────────────┘ Supervisor: Exposes Kubernetes + VM APIs Owns runtime enforcement VCF Automation: Consumes Supervisor APIs Provides self-service, governance, orchestration Supervisor enables capabilities VCF Automation operationalizes themvSphere

tenants-in-supervisor.html.title: Tenants in Supervisor
tenants-in-supervisor.html.description:
#tenancy In vSphere Supervisor a tenant is namespace-bound. There is no separate tenant object inside Kubernetes.
A Supervisor Namespace is the tenant boundary at the vSphere-Kubernetes interface. If you assume: Tenant = Project → you’ll design the wrong thing Tenant = Kubernetes namespace → you’ll under-secure Tenant = Supervisor Namespace → things line up “tenant namespace” is an informal shorthand for supervisor namespace. Organizations and Projects are governance overlays. They do not define the tenant.Kubernetes namespaces inside guest clusters are secondary scopes.
In vSphere Supervisor each tenant is realized as one (or more) Supervisor Namespaces.
VCF Automation sits above, provides governance (Organizations, Projects, quotas) and self-service, but does not define tenancy by itself.This is sometimes “informally” expressed as “tenant namespaces”. What is meant by it is a Supervisor Namespace.Or more precisely: In a Supervisor Cluster tenant == supervisor namespace (there is a 1-1 relationship).
In vSphere Supervisor, tenancy is realized through Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the execution and isolation boundary for tenants.When people say: “tenant namespace” “project namespace” “customer namespace” They almost always mean: A Supervisor Namespace allocated to that tenant. Kubernetes does not have a separate construct for this: It is a vSphere concept, projected as a namespace.A Supervisor Namespace can contain: Pods VMs Entire guest Kubernetes clusters Tenant └── Supervisor Namespace ├── VM workloads ├── Pod workloads └── Guest K8s Cluster └── many Kubernetes namespaces VCF Environment └── vSphere (vCenter) └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace ← TENANT BOUNDARY At this layer: Supervisor Namespace Has: Resource limits Storage policies Network segments RBAC bindings Is created and owned by vCenter Maps to: Resource pools NSX constructs Datastore permissions This is where hard multitenancy lives.

#tenancyThis is logical tenancy, not execution tenancy.Organization └── Project └── Deployment / Blueprint └── (Targets a Supervisor Namespace) Organization Business / administrative grouping Project Quota + governance container These map downwards, but they don’t execute workloads themselves.
Supervisor Namespace defines a tenant from a runtime and security perspective.
At VCF-A Organizations and Projects define: Ownership Billing
Governance Access workflows But not execution boundaries. VCF Environment (Rackspace) └── Supervisor Cluster ├── ns-cocacola ← Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-pepsi ← Tenant: Pepsi └── ns-pizzahut ← Tenant: Pizza Hut Each tenant is a supervisor namespace.
For Coca-Cola (example): Fixed CPU / memory quota Dedicated or isolated NSX segment Approved storage policies RBAC scoped to Coca-Cola admins Ability to run: Pods VMs Guest Kubernetes clusters That namespace is the tenant boundary. Layer VCF automation on top of this:Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke-Prod └── Deployments → targets ns-cocacola Organization: Pepsi └── Project: Pepsi-Shared └── Deployments → targets ns-pepsi Organizations and Projects map to Supervisor Namespaces — they do not replace them.Automation gives: Self-service catalogs Approval workflows Policy as code Lifecycle orchestration But the tenant still “lives” at the Supervisor Namespace.Scope vCenter Supervisor Cluster NSX Storage policies Responsibilities Create Supervisor Namespaces Set quotas Attach networks Bind tenant identities Enforce platform guardrails Power level God-mode Not visible to customers Scope One Supervisor Namespace (e.g., ns-cocacola) Kubernetes API within that namespace Responsibilities Manage workloads Deploy guest clusters Configure service Delegate access internally Cannot See other tenants Modify quotas Escape namespace This is who you hand the kubeconfig to. Scope Kubernetes RBAC inside tenant (supervisor) namespace Possibly inside guest clusters Responsibilities Deploy apps Manage services Consume secrets No infrastructure privileges Scope Automation policies Catalogs Projects Approvals This role: Often held by Rackspace Sometimes delegated partially to tenants
#secrets Secrets do not cross Supervisor Namespaces Identity trust roots often terminate there Network policy enforcement happens there Audit logs are scoped there So when you say tenant == Supervisor Namespace, then: Security Compliance Billing Automation all align clearly.

the-big-picture.html.title: The Big Picture
the-big-picture.html.description:
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment.
Multi-Tenancy
#tenancyTenants are Bound to ProjectsOutstanding action items: clarify path scheme of secrets understan how organization, projects, tenants, and namespaces tie together. What is a supervisor namespace, what makes it different than a Kubernetes namespace, are there other "namespace" concepts in VCF?

vm-workload-and-pod-workload.html.title: VM Workload and Pod Workload
vm-workload-and-pod-workload.html.description:
In VCF, a workload is: A unit of compute that consumes CPU, memory, storage, and networking, and is subject to lifecycle, policy, and governance. VCF doesn’t care what the workload is at a philosophical level. It cares about: How it is instantiated How it is isolated How it is scheduled How it is governed Which control plane owns it one machine per workloadA VM workload is a traditional virtual machine: Runs on ESX Has its own guest OS Is managed by vCenter Uses vSphere constructs directly
vCenter Server is the authoritative control plane VCF Automation wraps vCenter, but does not replace it CPU / memory allocated per VM Strong isolation via hypervisor boundaries Overcommitment controlled at ESX level Create VM Power on/off Snapshot Clone Patch guest OS Backup VM image VM policies Placement rules Affinity / anti-affinity HA / DRS Backup & DR policies many disposable units forming a service.A pod workload is a Kubernetes Pod running on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster.A pod on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster is not a traditional Kubernetes pod. It is a vSphere Pod — Kubernetes-shaped, but vSphere-implemented.Key point: A pod workload is not a VM pretending to be a container. Supervisor pods are VMs implementing container semantics, not containers implemented as VMs. A Supervisor pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose execution unit is a micro-VM, where the VM boundary replaces the Linux container boundary. The VM is the isolation primitive The Pod is the semantic primitive The container image is payload, not a process model So the VM is not “pretending to be a container” — it is implementing the Pod abstraction using a VM instead of a process. Pod (Kubernetes API object) └─ Backed by └─ Ultra-lightweight VM └─ ESX └─ Hardware It is: A Kubernetes-native unit Scheduled by Kubernetes Governed by Kubernetes APIs Backed by vSphere under the hood Kubernetes API (Supervisor cluster) is authoritative vCenter supplies infrastructure, not lifecycle semantics VCF Automation governs Kubernetes intent, not individual pods CPU / memory requested via Kubernetes requests & limits Scheduler decides placement Isolation via: Namespaces RBAC Pod security (Optionally) VM-backed pod runtimes Declarative (YAML) Reconciliation-based Pods are ephemeral Restart ≠ failure Replacement is normal Namespace-level quotas Admission control Image policies Network policies VM workloads → legacy, stateful, pet-like systems Pod workloads → cloud-native, stateless, cattle-like systems VCF’s value is: Running both on the same physical infrastructure, with unified policy and automation, without forcing one model onto the other. Trying to manage pods like VMs breaks Kubernetes. Trying to manage VMs like pods breaks operational reality.VCF keeps them separate but coordinated.
A pod workload in VCF is a Kubernetes-native execution unit scheduled and governed by the vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes control plane, consuming vSphere resources indirectly through Kubernetes abstractions—unlike a VM workload, which is a hypervisor-managed, OS-bearing unit directly governed by vCenter. “Pod workload” ≠ “small VM” Pod workloads are Kubernetes-first, not vSphere-first VMs are stateful machines Pods are replaceable execution instances VCF supports both because enterprises need both

vsphere-and-vcenter.html.title: vSphere and vCenter
vsphere-and-vcenter.html.description:
vSphere is the platform (the whole virtualization stack) vCenter Server is the control plane that manages the coordinates of that platform ESX is the hypervisor that runs on hardware and executes VMs. I mentally see (but don’t tell) this as “vSphere is just marketing”: There is nothing I can curl called vSphere. it is “air”. VMware vSphere is a product suite, not a single binary.To be clear: vSphere is a product name, or a platform name. Its components are the concrete things that actually do the work.vSphere includes: ESX is the bare-metal hypervisor.
vCenter Server provides centralized management. Platform features: vMotion (live VM migration) HA/DRS Resource pools Distributed switches Storage policies Fault tolerance You cannot have vSphere without ESX. You can have ESX without vCenter (but it will be very limited). Connects many ESX hosts. Maintains inventory and state Enforces cluster-level logic. Orchestrates features that require coordination. vMotion between hosts DRS placement decisions Cluster HA Supervisor Cluster (for Kubernetes / VCF) vCenter Server is a set of backend services: Inventory (hosts, clusters, VMs) State and configuration database
Scheduling logic (DRS)
HA coordination
vMotion orchestration RBAC, roles, permissions APIs (REST, SOAP)

There is exactly ONE UI name (“vSphere Client”), but it can connect to TWO different backends. vSphere Server ESX Hosts ## Mode 1 Browser ↓ ESX Host ↓ Embedded vSphere Client ## Mode 2 Browser ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere Client ↓ Many ESX hosts
A vSphere Cluster is a logical grouping of ESX hosts that vCenter treats as a single resource pool and failure domain. It exists only in vCenter ESX hosts do not know they are “in a cluster”. When you create a cluster in vCenter Server, you are telling: “*These ESX hosts agree to be scheduled, balanced, and failed over together.”This enables cluster-level logic, such as DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler): vCenter decides which host should run which VM. When to rebalance the load.
Uses vMotion to move VMs between hosts. HA (High Availability) Hosts run a lightweight HA agent. If a host dies: Other hosts detect it vCenter (or preconfigured HA logic) restarts VMs elsewhere. Shared resource abstraction Instead of thinking: Host A: 64 cores Host B: 64 cores vCenter presents Cluster: 128 cores VM placement and limits are logical, not physical.A vSphere Cluster is not:Because from an operator’s perspective: Hosts act like a pool Failures are absorbed Workloads move transparently But architecturally: The cluster is an illusion created by vCenter.
A vSphere cluster is a vCenter-defined scheduling and failure domain over multiple ESX hosts,[ Physical Servers ] ↓ ESX (many hosts) ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere features & automation

headers.heading: Why VMware still calls it a “cluster”

vsphere-client.html.title: vSphere Client
vsphere-client.html.description:
VMware vSphere Client is: A web UI (HTML5 / JS) Running inside either ESX (embedded) or vCenter Consuming backend APIs It consumes REST and legacy SOAP / internal APIs Functionally: It is an API consumer It behaves differently depending on where it is placed: Same UI codebase: Connected to ESX → host-scoped Connected to vCenter Server → environment-scoped The UI is not “smart”: The backend defines reality.vSphere is a product contract, not a system.
ESX and vCenter are the systems that implement that contract.

vsphere-construct.html.title: vSphere construct
vsphere-construct.html.description:
A vSphere construct is: *A first-class infrastructure object that is _natively defined, owned, and enforced by the vSphere control plane (ESX + vCenter), not by Kubernetes or higher-level automation layers. Think of it as a primitive in vSphere’s own vocabulary.Below are objects that exist because vSphere exists — they are not abstractions layered on top. Virtual Machine vCPU vNUMA vApp Resource Pool Shares / Limits / Reservations DRS rules HA admission control Datastore vSAN object VM disk (VMDK) Storage policy Port Group Distributed Virtual Switch VM NIC VLAN / overlay constructs Snapshot Clone vMotion Storage vMotion HA restart Fault Tolerance All of these are authoritative in VMware vSphere and enforced by: VMware ESXi VMware vCenter Server These are foreign concepts to vSphere — it may host them, but it does not own them: Kubernetes Pod Kubernetes Deployment Kubernetes Service Kubernetes ReplicaSet Kubernetes Namespace (in the K8s sense) Kubernetes ServiceAccount vSphere sees these as resource consumers, not objects with meaning.A VM Workload is built entirely out of vSphere constructs.
A Pod Workload is built out of Kubernetes constructs, even though it ultimately consumes vSphere resources.## VM Workload VM ├─ vCPU ├─ vMemory ├─ VMDK ├─ Port Group └─ Resource Pool Pod ├─ Container ├─ CPU request/limit ├─ Memory request/limit ├─ ServiceAccount └─ Namespace

headers.heading: What counts as a vSphere construct

why-does-supervisor-exist.html.title: Why Does Supervisor Exist
why-does-supervisor-exist.html.description: Kubernetes didn’t replace VMs. It replaced application scheduling semantics.VMware’s bet was: "Instead of forcing Kubernetes to run on top of vSphere, we'll make Kubernetes a native execution mode of vSphere." Supervisor is that bet made concrete. vSphere = substrate Supervisor = Kubernetes-native personality of vSphere VCF Automation = enterprise automation layer on top vSphere Supervisor

blueprint.html.title: Blueprint
blueprint.html.description:
A Blueprint is a declarative deployment template that defines what can be requested, how it is configured, where it may land, and under which policies and approvals.Blueprints live in VCF Automation.
Blueprints in VCF Automation are governed deployment templates that define allowed workload patterns, configuration inputs, placement constraints, and approval policies. They orchestrate resource creation but are not part of the runtime execution layer.Once a deployment is created, the Blueprint can be deleted and the workload keeps running: It’s not part of the runtime layer.User ↓ Blueprint ← governance + intent ↓ Project ← who / where / policy ↓ Supervisor Namespace ↓ vSphere / Kubernetes runtime Kubernetes YAML answers: “How do I create this thing?” Blueprints answer: “Who is allowed to create which thing, under what rules, and with whose approval?” Organization: business boundary (e.g. Verizon)
Project: governance scope (e.g. US-East) Blueprint: allowed patterns inside that scope Organization: Verizon └── Project: US-East ├── Blueprint: Standard App VM ├── Blueprint: GPU Pod └── Blueprint: 3-Node K8s Cluster Each Blueprint: targets specific Supervisor Namespace(s) enforces constraints hides complexity from requesters Typically it defines:Examples: A VM A vSphere Pod A Guest Kubernetes cluster A multi-tier app (VM + LB + storage) CPU / memory sizes Environment variables Image versions Feature toggles Secret references (not secret values)
Which Supervisor Namespace(s) are allowed Which storage policies are allowed Which networks are allowed Size limits Placement rules Who can request it Who must approve it Lease duration Cost visibility / chargeback tags
Supervisor Namespace

headers.heading: How Blueprints relate to Projects and Tenants

project.html.title: Project
project.html.description: VCF Automation supports both one-to-one and one-to-many mappings between Projects and Supervisor Namespaces; the choice is an architectural pattern, not a platform constraint.Very common, very clean:Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev Why teams choose this Clean blast-radius isolation Clear RBAC and quotas per environment Easy mental model Common in regulated / prod-heavy setups This is a design choice, not a platform requirement.(Equally valid, also common in larger deployments)Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod Why teams choose this Shared governance (same people, same blueprints) Environment separation handled at namespace level Easier cross-env promotion workflows Fewer projects to manage

secrets-federation-notes.html.title: Secrets Federation Notes
secrets-federation-notes.html.description: #todo TODO: remove this from the docs once I have a good enough template for the solution. Many tenants (Pepsi, Coca Cola, Sprite, Pizza Hut) Each tenant has an external Vault (or Vault instance) with paths that can overlap: credentials/db/finance is a common example Sync into an internal OpenBao (or internal Vault) via ESO Inject into workloads via Vault Sidecar Injector You want no path collisions and no possibility of cross-tenant access There are two separate problems: Storage namespace collision in internal OpenBao Runtime authorization when workloads fetch secrets (injection) this is the first half of the problem.Based on the official VCF Secret Service docs, a lot of the “last-mile consumption” is already solved (create secret → store it → inject it into pods/VMs as files), but tenancy isolation is explicitly coarse and largely stops at the Supervisor Namespace boundary. It’s there, but it’s not the fine-grained. That is any OpenBao secret bound to a namespace is visible to any workload in that namespace.That should be fine since tenants are effectively namespace-bound.The “Managing Secrets…” doc spells out delivery formats: vSphere Pods → file mount under /vault/secrets/<user-provided-name> VM Service VMs → disk-based transfer + read-only mount VKS (guest) cluster pods → file mount similar to vSphere Pods This solves consistent delivery semantics per workload type. All service accounts have read access to all secrets of that namespace. ^ that is the granularity we get. Which may or may not be fine based on the customers’ requirements.Also it’s worth noting that any notion of Organization/Project tenancy in the Secret Store model does not exist by architecture (which is also fine because secrets are namespace-bound, and tenants are also namespace-bound).None of the flows refer to Organization/Project at all. They are consistently “pick a Supervisor namespace; secrets live there”.That’s consistent with what we discussed earlier: governance constructs don’t appear at runtime.The docs show a pattern like secret/data/<namespace>/<secretName> for retrieval. Secrets are stored in a “corresponding namespace” (meaning: per Supervisor namespace). VKS isolation is only at Supervisor namespace level (explicit). Within a namespace, all service accounts can read all secrets (explicit). So the tenancy story is not missing — it’s just coarse: Tenant isolation = Supervisor Namespace isolation (and nothing finer is guaranteed). A safe mapping consistent with the doc’s retrieval convention would look like: External: credentials/db/finance Internal: secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/credentials/db/finance (or secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/<some-secret-name> that contains those K/Vs) That avoids cross-tenant collisions because the Supervisor namespace becomes the first path segment.According to the docs, all tenants share the same unified internal secrets store (OpenBao).In the doc’s annotation model, you specify a secret “path” in the injector annotation. They show: vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-secret-...: "secret/data/demo/db-cred" Inject Secrets in to a vSphere … So for Pepsi, if you used the flattened name approach, you’d inject like: secret/data/pepsi/auth__finance__db__creds …and because the auth role is tied to the namespace (example role demo), Pepsi workloads would authenticate with role pepsi and read from the pepsi/* prefix. ✅ In this doc model, within a tenant’s Supervisor namespace, any Pepsi workload can access any Pepsi secret. ❌ Restricting secrets to only pods in a specific Kubernetes namespace inside the tenant is not supported here (especially for VKS guest clusters). ✅ OpenBao paths look like secret/data/<supervisor-namespace>/<secretName> (KV v2 style). ✅ In shared OpenBao, prevent collisions by ensuring the first path segment is the tenant namespace (pepsi, cocacola, …). VCF Secret Store Service does have guardrails that prevent a Coca-Cola workload from mounting Pepsi secrets, as long as you stay within the supported model.But those guardrails are namespace-scoped, not “tenant-aware in the abstract”, and they rely on how identities and roles are provisioned, not on OpenBao magically inferring tenancy.The guardrails are not: “OpenBao automatically understands tenants” “Vault paths are globally protected by magic” They are: The Vault/OpenBao token that a workload receives is issued in the context of a specific Supervisor Namespace. That token is not shared across namespaces. So: A Coca-Cola workload never gets the same token as a Pepsi workload Tokens are not reusable across namespaces This is enforced by Supervisor, not by Kubernetes RBAC alone.The injector examples in the docs consistently show: a role name tied to the namespace (e.g. demo) secrets read from secret/data/<namespace>/... That implies (and matches how VMware typically wires these systems): Each Supervisor Namespace has a corresponding OpenBao role and policy. You don’t see the policy YAML in the docs, but the model only works if: role pepsi → policy allows secret/data/pepsi/* role cocacola → policy allows secret/data/cocacola/* Otherwise the examples would be unsafe. A pod can’t just arbitrarily say: vault.hashicorp.com/agent-inject-secret-foo: secret/data/pepsi/db from another namespace, because: the injector runs with Supervisor context the auth role used is bound to the namespace the token issued is constrained by that role So even if a Coca-Cola pod requests a Pepsi path, the read fails. That’s the critical point: request ≠ authorization. ref: “All service accounts have read access to all secrets of that namespace.” That sentence is not saying: “All namespaces can read all secrets.” It’s saying: “Within one Supervisor Namespace, we don’t give you finer-grained scoping.” If we ensure that: Pepsi secrets are materialized under secret/data/pepsi/... Coca-Cola secrets under secret/data/cocacola/... Then VCF Secret Store Service guardrails already align with that: Pepsi workloads authenticate as “Pepsi namespace” Pepsi role can only read secret/data/pepsi/* Coca-Cola role cannot read Pepsi paths So yes: If we respect the namespace-prefix contract, the rest of the consumption plumbing is already handled safely by VCF Secret Store Service. We are not punching a hole in the security model by doing the sync.The model breaks only if you bypass the intended trust boundaries, for example: A single ESO instance with a token that can write/read all tenant prefixes Manually creating secrets in the wrong namespace Reusing roles or tokens across namespaces Exposing OpenBao externally and letting workloads authenticate out-of-band Those are operator errors, not product gaps — but they’re exactly what auditors look for.VCF Secret Store Service enforces tenant isolation at the Supervisor Namespace boundary by issuing namespace-scoped identities and policies for secret access. As long as tenant secrets are materialized under their corresponding namespace paths, cross-tenant secret access is prevented by design. Fine-grained intra-namespace isolation is intentionally not provided.

supervisor-and-supervisor-cluster.html.title: Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster
supervisor-and-supervisor-cluster.html.description:
A mode / capability of a vSphere cluster
Means: “This vSphere cluster has Kubernetes enabled and is running the Supervisor control plane” or less wordy: “*a vSphere cluster with Supervisor enabled”. Not a physical thing by itself
Think of it as a feature flag + control plane. A vSphere cluster with Supervisor enabled
A concrete, addressable object: ESXi hosts
vCenter-managed cluster
Supervisor control plane VMs This is what you actually connect to with kubectl
In practice, people often say:
“deploy this on Supervisor”
“connect to the Supervisor”
“namespace on Supervisor”
What they mean is: “the Kubernetes API exposed by the Supervisor-enabled vSphere cluster”
So colloquially: Supervisor ≈ Supervisor Cluster
But technically:
Supervisor = the Kubernetes capability
Supervisor Cluster = the vSphere cluster running it

vcenter-server.html.title: vCenter Server
vcenter-server.html.description: vCenter Server runs as a Virtual Appliance (VCSA) — a prebuilt VM — on ESX.Concretely: vCenter is not bare metal It is deployed as an OVA That OVA becomes one VM (sometimes functionally “a group of services”, but still a single VM) Internally, that VM runs: A hardened Linux-based OS vCenter services Database (embedded or external, depending on scale) Physical hardware └── ESX └── vCenter Server Appliance (VM) └── vCenter services

vcf-automation-and-vcf-operations.html.title: VCF Automation and VCF Operations
vcf-automation-and-vcf-operations.html.description:
VCF-O does not: Own tenancy boundaries Gate workload creation Enforce business approval flows Define org/project constructs Those remain in: VCF-A Supervisor Upstream automation layers VCF-O observes those constructs after the fact. Day 0 / Day 1 → VCF-A - Who can create? - What can be created? - Under what policies? Day 2 → VCF-O - Is it healthy? - Is it over/under-utilized? - Is it behaving strangely? VCF (the platform) ├── VCF Automation (formerly Aria Automation) ├── VCF Operations (formerly Aria Operations) ├── Supervisor / vSphere └── Workloads Here is how things looks from each layer’s point of view:
Once a workload cluster is instantiated in a Supervisor Namespace, it has no awareness of VCF Automation constructs such as Organization or Project—Those concepts exist only at the governance layer (VCF-A) and are not part of the runtime execution model (Supervisor).

vcloud-director.html.title: vCloud Director
vcloud-director.html.description:
VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is a cloud-management and multi-tenancy layer built on top of vSphere. It was designed primarily for service providers (ISPs, telcos, MSPs) to offer VMware-based clouds to multiple customers in a clean, isolated, self-service way. vSphere → virtualization engine (hypervisors, clusters, VMs) VCD → cloud abstraction + multi-tenant control plane VCF → opinionated full stack (compute + storage + networking + ops) vSphere does not have native multitenancy, VCD enables multitenancy. VCD → sell VMware-based cloud to others VCF Automation → run your own internal cloud Cloud Layer ──────────── vCloud Director ← multi-tenant cloud manager Automation Layer ──────────── VCF Automation / Aria Automation Infrastructure ──────────── vSphere + vSAN + NSX Hardware ──────────── Bare metal


No. vSphere = hypervisor + cluster management VCD = separate product that consumes vSphere
VMware’s product web pages for Cloud Director explicitly state that VCD operates within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform as an integrated cloud-management layer: VCD is described as helping to “[efficiently […] operate and manage your managed private and public cloud services using VMware Cloud Director within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform](VMware Cloud Director | Leading Cloud Service Delivery Platform.However, in the baseline VCF component lists and core architectural docs, the docs list things like vSphere, vSAN, NSX, SDDC Manager, VCF Automation but not VCD as a base building block. *Historically: no. Today: “it depends on the SKU and use case.”** VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is aimed at: Enterprises Private cloud Platform teams
Automation (VCF Automation) VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is aimed at: Service providers Telcos Hosted private cloud Customer-facing tenancy VCF does not require VCD, and most enterprise VCF deployments do not use it.

Is vCloud Director part of VCF?

virtual-appliance.html.title: Virtual Appliance
virtual-appliance.html.description:
A VMware appliance is a prepackaged, hardened virtual machine that bundles an OS, application, configuration, and lifecycle tooling into a single deployable unit.A VMware-style appliance typically includes: A minimal, locked-down OS The application(s) Configuration defaults Upgrade mechanisms Health checks Backup/restore hooks Support boundaries (“only change things this way”) The key idea is: You manage the appliance as a product, not as a general-purpose OS. Usually yes, but conceptually they can be: One VM (vCenter) Multiple tightly-coupled VMs (some NSX / telco components) But still treated as one product unit From the operator’s perspective: You deploy “the appliance” You don’t manage its internals individually Once you accept that: vCenter is a VM Supervisor components are appliances Then the stack becomes very consistent: ESX runs everything
vCenter Server orchestrates everything
Appliances are how VMware ships control planes Kubernetes is just another control surface layered on top Multiple VMs ≠ appliance unless:If you deploy 3 random VMs and wire them together yourself — that’s not an appliance.
VCF Automation

headers.heading: How this differs from “just deploying multiple VMs”

vsphere-pod.html.title: vSphere Pod
vsphere-pod.html.description:
A vSphere Pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose sandbox runs inside a lightweight VM (via ESX]), not inside a container runtime on a shared Linux node.So: API semantics → Kubernetes Runtime semantics → vSphere / VM Traditional Kubernetes Pods: Share a Linux kernel Rely on namespaces + cgroups Are fast and efficient But have weaker isolation (from a hypervisor POV) vSphere Pods were created to: Give VM-grade isolation While keeping Pod-level developer UX For multi-tenant / regulated environments This matters a lot for: Service providers Telco Regulated enterprise workloads “Pods from different customers must never share a kernel” Regular Kubernetes:Node (Linux) └── kubelet ├── Pod A ├── Pod B └── Pod C vSphere Pods:ESXi ├── Pod-VM A ├── Pod-VM B └── Pod-VM C No shared container runtime No shared kubelet per “node” Each pod is scheduled directly by vSphere Kubernetes still thinks it’s scheduling Pods — but vSphere translates that into VM placement.So in vSphereland, “One Pod ~= Tiny VM”


Kubernetes: Decides which pod should run vSphere: Decides where the pod-VM runs Enforces CPU, memory, NUMA, HA, DRS This is what “Kubernetes-native mode” really looks like under the hood. From the Pod’s perspective: It has an IP It mounts volumes It exposes ports Under the hood: Networking is NSX-backed Storage is datastore-policy-backe Attach/detach happens at VM granularity Again: Pod UX, VM machinery. Despite the VM runtime, vSphere Pods still use: Pod specs Containers Init containers ConfigMaps Volume mounts Pod lifecycle (create/delete/restart) Kubernetes Services (with some constraints) So developers mostly don’t care—and that is by design. Regular Pod → process in a shared OS vSphere Pod → process in its own micro-VM Or: Regular K8s → Linux container model vSphere Pods → “micro-VM container” model Essentially: vSphere Pods are not regular Kubernetes Pods They are Pod-shaped workloads backed by per-Pod VMs Kubernetes API semantics remain intact Runtime isolation is hypervisor-level This is intentional and central to Supervisor’s design

headers.heading: Scheduling is Co-Owned By K8s and vSphere

vsphere,-esx,-and-vcenter.html.title: vSphere, ESX, and vCenter
vsphere,-esx,-and-vcenter.html.description:
Saying “vSphere is ESX and vCenter” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.Because vSphere is a platform, it is NOT a single product.vSphere is VMware’s virtualization platform built on ESX hosts managed by vCenter Server, together providing cluster-level services such as HA, DRS, and Kubernetes integration.But still, that term is mostly, contextually “good enough” because, in practice: You never run production vSphere without vCenter ESX alone is just a hypervisor, not a platform vCenter alone does nothing Type-1 (bare-metal) hypervisor Runs directly on hardware Owns: CPU scheduling Memory management Device virtualization Does not coordinate clusters by itself You can run standalone ESXi without vCenter, but: No clustering
No HA
No DRS
No vMotion orchestration Centralized control plane Manages:
ESX hosts Clusters Resource pools Policies Orchestrates: vMotion DRS HA Lifecycle vCenter does not run workloads — it tells ESX what to do. In ESX, there is no general-purpose userland like you’d expect in Linux or Windows.ESX is a purpose-built, bare-metal hypervisor operating system whose kernel (VMkernel) directly manages hardware resources and runs virtual machines.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
